newsitem.title: USA: West African, Latam crudes beckon U.S. refiners.
newsitem.headline: West African, Latam crudes beckon U.S. refiners.

text.p: A variety of West African and Latin American crudes beckoned U.S. Gulf Coast refiners on Monday, while North Sea crudes remained pricey, traders said.
The spread between April West Texas Intermediate/Cushing and North Sea Brent sank to around $1.30-35 cents a barrel Monday afternoon, down 10 cents from Friday afternoon.
Despite falling CFD prices, traders saw little chance that Brent would head toward the Gulf.
Brent was assessed at a discount of five cents to WTI/Cushing, costly in light of the availability of West African and Latin American barrels.
Swiss-based trading house Glencore was supposedly working a ULCC to the Gulf, but traders speculated that the cargoes would be sold into Europe or sold off into the market instead.
From West Africa, Bonny Light and Qua Iboe were assessed at April WTI plus 35-45 cents a barrel for end-March early April delivery, while Forcades was at a premium of around 15-20 cents.
On the Latin American front, two out of an original five cargoes of Colombian Cano Limon loading in March were still available, traders said.
The prices ranged from WTI/Cushing minus $2.50 a barrel for prompt loading, to minus $2.25 a barrel for end-March loading.
Exxon bought at least two cargoes of Cano Limon recently, quelling earlier speculation that the U.S. major had cut off spot purchases of the grade.
